race.name: Heywood Ride
race.tagline: Heywood Ride. 50 miles of gravel through Northfield.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Minnesota countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Minnesota event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Heywood Ride is a local event in Minnesota‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Minnesota countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Minnesota gravel race. Worth it for Minnesota/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Minnesota‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Minnesota races: Almanzo, Dirty Benjamin.

logistics.food: Northfield has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: camping available at Sechler Park (no facilities, no big rigs/trailers)

non_negotiables.why: Minnesota rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Central Park in Northfield provides a clear start location with 30-minute check-in requirements, but the event explicitly tells you to "bring cash" for stops and warns that aid stations "MIGHT show up" or might not. Run by three people‚ÄîMarty, Ben, and Mike‚Äîthis is intentionally minimal logistics by design, not oversight.

length.explanation: Atsuko targeted a 14 mph pace for the 60-mile distance but found herself "doing 18+ mph" at the start and deliberately "let myself drift backwards through the crowd" to avoid blowing up. Her final average of 11.3 mph over 58.39 miles reflects the rolling terrain slowing ambitious early pacing. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The Minimum Maintenance Road climb is "the main attraction, big-ticket event" with its "seemingly vertical wall of gravel strewn with riders," while Atsuko "had to walk the Shady Lane climb." Otherwise, surfaces are "downright pleasant" gravel where "nearly any tire will work, though we suggest staying above 32c." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The course features "three climbs, all about the same length, each immediately followed by a speedy descent back down." Dustin describes the MMR climb as multiple pitches requiring momentum and line selection, while the overall profile varies "from long rollers to short, punchy climbs" through farm country. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: May weather swings wildly year to year‚Äî2024 brought building heat with 20-30 mph headwinds, while 2025 was a "rudely chilly day" at 50¬∞F after "2 weeks of shorts and T-shirt conditions." Atsuko wore "every single layer of clothing I brought" including kneewarmers and a buff. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: This is Minnesota farm country south of Minneapolis starting from Central Park at essentially sea level. The highest point you'll reach is the top of those rolling agricultural hills, which aren't going to challenge anyone's oxygen intake. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The course passes Oxford Mill ruins "an old grain mill along the river that operated from 1878 to 1905" and descends to the Little Cannon River "along winding rural roads surrounded by greenery and farmland." Riders can choose distances on the day itself, adding route flexibility to the countryside exploration.

prestige.explanation: Dustin describes it as gravel riding "without the self-seriousness and pressure of the increasingly competitive modern gravel racing scene." Organizer Marty Larson is explicit: "This is just a bike ride. We're doing this to provide a space for people to come and ride their bikes. It's not an expo."

race_quality.explanation: The event warns that aid stations "MIGHT be unsanctioned" and "We don't control where they will go, or if they will show up. Be prepared to not have any!" This is an intentional grassroots approach run by three core organizers plus spouses and volunteers, not organizational chaos.

experience.explanation: Riders follow the Cannon River northeast through "some of the nicest and prettiest of the ride, descending down a valley to the Little Cannon River" before the brutal final stretch‚Äîa "long straight back into town" with 20-30 mph headwinds that had Dustin "crawling along" and reaching for an emergency caffeine gel.

community.explanation: Registration is $25 regardless of distance with a "pay for another rider" program where around 100 riders typically contribute. The event has "no sponsors, no podium, is not a race" and explicitly states "If you need financial support, this community fund has your back, no questions asked."

field_depth.explanation: Dustin's training consists of "bike-commuting on my e-cargo bike 3-4 times per week" and "occasional party/pastry-paced social ride," which reflects the participatory rather than competitive field. The event allows e-bikes including cargo bikes with toddlers on back, welcoming all cycling flavors equally. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $25 registration covers any distance from 30 to 390 miles, with the original pay-what-you-want model still supporting riders who need it. The community fund removes financial barriers entirely, while post-ride festivities include "music and food trucks at the finish line" in tree-covered Central Park.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Free camping is offered at Sechler Park for "Camper van or rooftop tent" setups, while Nerstrand State Park and Caron Park sit ten minutes from the start line. Northfield offers "caf√©s, bakeries, and lots of stores with actual personality" plus three breweries in a college town setting. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: The Heywood Ride 2022
videos.description: Two hour time lapse in 2 minutes

videos.title: The Heywood!
videos.description:
Join me for highlights from the 2025 Heywood Ride in beautiful Northfield, Minnesota! This gravel biking event brings together cyclists from all over for an unforgettable day of riding, community, and Midwest scenery.

üé• Featuring:

Bikes

Scenic gravel routes

Event atmosphere

üëç Like, Subscribe & hit the bell for more cycling events and coverage!

#HeywoodRide #NorthfieldMN #GravelCycling #BikeEvent #MinnesotaCycling #Heywood2025




http://instagram.com/area45

videos.title: The Heywood 55 gravel cycling 2024 edition
videos.description:
53 mile gravel cycling ride in Northfield, MN 5/18/24

Music: Hot Shot by Scott Holmes Music

quotes.text: The ride itself was great, but it was really cold and because I'm from the city, I really wasn't prepared for the cold weather that we had. It's in the 40s, but it feels like it's in the 30s.

I feel like this event was more about the people for sure. I think I could have left my bike at home and still had a great time this weekend. The writing was just kind of in between all the fun hangs and the great conversations.
